It may return an io error.

div.p: Operations do NOT need to be thread-safe.
At any time, there is up to one thread reading or modifying this struct: job().
However all operations do need to work on an immutably borrowed self.

div.div:
enum Entry<'a, K, V> {
Ref(( &'a K, &'a V )),
Own(Res<( K, V )>),
}
+ try_borrow() -> Res<( &'a K, &'a V )>
+ take_kv() -> Res<( K, V )>
etc

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 798px; height: 1px; padding-top: 3247px; margin-left: 4002px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

ul.li: Impl:
Convert Iterators to Streams.
Advantages:
Performance benefit due to concurrent file I/O?
Disadvantages:
Performance penalty due to increased switching between async/await futures?
Run one flushing+compacting job per index.
Impl:
Each LsmTree contains its own Task.
Advantages:
It's easier to write the job logic for prioritizing certain slices over others.
Disadvantages:
Need to manage Task-switching, while still prioritizing flushing, while also avoiding starvation of any jobs.
Thrread-per-core.
Impl:
Indexes are partitioned and assigned to CPU cores.
Each core operates a single thread: an actor that accepts requests for any of the 1+ indexes assigned to the core.
get one
get range
push commit
flush/compact & replace
For transactions:
Each message contains a oneshot channel, which delivers the query result to the transaction task.
For the "get SV range" operation, two indexes are involved: 1) the SI executes "get range", 2) the SI sends a request to the PI, 3) the PI sends the result to the transaction task.
Does there need to be a thread/task pool that runs all transactions and flushing+compacting job(s)?
The logical usage of indexes by any {user operation, job} becomes equivalent to acquiring a mutex on each index for the duration of each index API call.
Advantages:
Better caching of RAM? (This pertains mostly to memtables in commits?)
Better caching of inodes?
Disadvantages:
GC job prioritization strategy.
(Proposal) When compacting MemLogs, read the gap multiset. The interval in between each held version is mergeable.

li.span: Bonus if we can use a Dict that can be read locklessly. Is it possible?

ul.li: (Proposal) Notification of list version should be per-LsmTree ?
Performance improvements around conflict-checking and committing.
Early detection of conflicts?
Transactions should handle large data.
Impl:

written_* is an LSMTree, rather than just a WritableMemLog. This txn-local LSMTree is flushed and compacted, just like any other LSMTree. The flushing+compaction might be done synchronously within the txn Task, rather than by the global GC job.

div.div:
Every committed entryset contains info on [lo_incl ... hi_incl] commit ver range, and not just one commit ver.
For traversing operations, the distinction between lo and hi is irrelevant. All commit version ranges encountered in a traversal are sorted and contiguous (and mostly disjoint). And none of the [lo..hi] ranges crosses over min_separate_commit_ver.
The range is required for deduping entrysets upon bootup, in case GC failed to remove dirs belonging to dangling entrysets.
Among entrysests that overlap in commit ver range, the one entryset with the newest timestamp is loaded, and all other entrysets are discarded.
Timestamp is just a monotonically increasing integer, and is not correlated with the system clock.

switch.text: Every committed entryset contains info on [lo_incl ... hi_in...

div.div:
enum CommittedEntrySet<K, V> {
RMemLog( ReadonlyMemLog<K,V> ),
SSTable( SSTable<K,V> ),
}
+ load(CommittedEntrySetInfo) -> Res<Self>
+ get_one(&Q) -> Opt<Entry<K, OptDat<V>>>
+ get_range(Opt<&Q>, Opt<&Q>) -> Iter<Entry<K, OptDat<V>>>
+ info() -> &CommittedEntrySetInfo

// This fn constructs Txn and passes it to cb. Cb must call `txn.close()`.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 478px; height: 1px; padding-top: 47px; margin-left: 3642px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;

ul.li: Under lsm/
Unordered id for avoiding collision of entryset-* dirs
Under scnd_idxs/
Unordered id for avoiding collision of scnd_idx-* dirs
Txn creates a writable entryset
(Not a use case: Txn commit does not create a new entryset)
GC job creates a new entryset
Scnd idx creation job creates a new entryset
Scnd idx creation request creates a new scnd_idx-* dir

Given the above listed concurrent use cases of unique_id, we need Arc<Mutex<_>>.
The entire db could share one u64. But, to reduce contention and to simplify code organization, we choose to let each LSM and the DB own its own id.

div.div: This is a simplistic query engine. Each "get" statement requires exactly one index to run on. A "select where" statement depends on exactly one secondary index, and if a matching one is not found, then the statement fails.
create new empty itvset and insert into dict;

div.span: Compacting SSTables may be less urgent than flushing Memtables.
For now, always proceed to sstables.

display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.span:
Legend:
"slice" = the slice to replace or delete
K := the node immediately newer than the slice.
J := the newest node included in the slice.
H := the oldest node included in the slice.

G := the node immediate older than the slice.
R := the node to replace the slice with

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 478px; height: 1px; padding-top: 3087px; margin-left: 2082px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.span: timestamp: max(ts for ts in slice) + 1

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 514px; height: 1px; padding-top: 2129px; margin-left: 3764px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.span: /* Create a terminus dummy node in order to prevent the GC job from
/* Get the current leading commit ver, but don't `hold()` it.
It's possible for this job to redundantly work on (commit vers >= job_ver_ceil),
but it's better than blocking (commit vers >= job_ver_ceil) from
being merged by the GC job. */
/* This dict.get() is expected to always succeed, because
scnd idx deletion should abort if is_built == false. */

div.span: /* This call removes entryset dirs. Call it before the larger-scope `rm -r` below. */
return "Unable to delete all dangling slices. Memory leak!";
